stanza.line: O how much more doth beauty beauteous (a)seem(/a)
By that sweet ornament which truth doth (b)give(/b)
The rose looks fair but fairer we it (a)deem(/a)
For that sweet odour which doth in it (b)live(/b)
The canker blooms have full as deep a (c)dye(/c)
As the perfumed tincture of the (d)roses(/d)
Hang on such thorns and play as (c)wantonly(/c)
When summer's breath their masked buds (d)discloses(/d)
But for their virtue only is their (e)show(/e)
Die to themselves Sweet roses do not (e)so(/e)
Of their sweet deaths are sweetest odours (f)made(/f)
And so of you beauteous and lovely (g)youth(/g)
When that shall vade by verse distills your (g)truth(/g)
